   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading">Albania</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="vector-body"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" lang="en" dir="ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Albania_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Albania (disambiguation)">Albania (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in Southeastern Europe
      </div> 
      <p class="mw-empty-elt"> </p>

          </div><br>

          </div></th>
        </tr>

          <div style="line-height:1.2em;">
           <b>Motto:&nbsp;</b><a href="/wiki/Ti_Shqip%C3%ABri,_m%C3%AB_jep_nder,_m%C3%AB_jep_emrin_Shqip%C3%ABtar" title="Ti Shqipëri, më jep nder, më jep emrin Shqipëtar">Ti Shqipëri, më jep nder,<br>më jep emrin Shqipëtar</a>
           <br><span style="font-size:85%;">You Albania, give me honour,<br>you give me the name Albanian</span>

      <p><b>Albania</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/æ/: 'a' in 'bad'">æ</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'b' in 'buy'">b</span><span title="/eɪ/: 'a' in 'face'">eɪ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="/i/: 'y' in 'happy'">i</span><span title="/ə/: 'a' in 'about'">ə</span></span>,<span class="wrap"> </span><span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ɔː/: 'au' in 'fraud'">ɔː</span><span title="'l' in 'lie'">l</span></span>-/</a></span> <span class="nowrap" style="font-size:85%">(<span class="unicode haudio"><span class="fn"><span style="white-space:nowrap;margin-right:.25em;"><a href="/wiki/File:En-us-Albania.ogg" title="About this sound"><img alt="About this sound" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/11px-Loudspeaker.svg.png" decoding="async" width="11" height="11" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/17px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/Loudspeaker.svg/22px-Loudspeaker.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="20" data-file-height="20"></a></span><a href="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b3/En-us-Albania.ogg" class="internal" title="En-us-Albania.ogg">listen</a></span></span>)</span></span> <a href="/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key" title="Help:Pronunciation respelling key"><i title="English pronunciation respelling">a(w)l-<span style="font-size:90%">BAY</span>-nee-ə</i></a>; <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a>: <i lang="sq">Shqipëri</i> or <i lang="sq" title="Albanian-language text">Shqipëria</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[a]</a></sup> officially the <b>Republic of Albania</b> (<a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a>: <i lang="sq">Republika e Shqipërisë</i>),<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[b]</a></sup> is a country in <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeastern Europe</a>. It is located on the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ionian_Sea" title="Ionian Sea">Ionian Sea</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>, and shares <a href="/wiki/Land_border" class="mw-redirect" title="Land border">land borders</a> with <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> to the northwest, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a><span style="font-size:85%;"><sup id="cite_ref-status_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-status-9">[c]</a></sup></span> to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/North_Macedonia" title="North Macedonia">North Macedonia</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a> to the south; and <a href="/wiki/Maritime_border" class="mw-redirect" title="Maritime border">maritime borders</a> with Greece, Montenegro and <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a> to the west. <a href="/wiki/Tirana" title="Tirana">Tirana</a> is its capital and largest city, followed by <a href="/wiki/Durr%C3%ABs" title="Durrës">Durrës</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vlor%C3%AB" title="Vlorë">Vlorë</a> and <a href="/wiki/Shkod%C3%ABr" title="Shkodër">Shkodër</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Albania" title="Geography of Albania">Geographically</a>, Albania displays varied climatic, geological, hydrological, and morphological conditions, defined in an area of 28,748&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (11,100&nbsp;sq&nbsp;mi). It possesses significant diversity with the landscape ranging from the snow-capped mountains in the <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Alps" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Alps">Albanian Alps</a> as well as the <a href="/wiki/Korab" title="Korab">Korab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_Mountain_Range,_Albania#Skanderbeg_Mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Central Mountain Range, Albania">Skanderbeg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pindus_Mountains" class="mw-redirect" title="Pindus Mountains">Pindus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ceraunian_Mountains" title="Ceraunian Mountains">Ceraunian Mountains</a> to the hot and sunny coasts of the <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Adriatic_Sea_Coast" title="Albanian Adriatic Sea Coast">Albanian Adriatic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Ionian_Sea_Coast" title="Albanian Ionian Sea Coast">Ionian Sea</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Basin" title="Mediterranean Basin">Mediterranean Sea</a>. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/History_of_Albania" title="History of Albania">Historically</a>, Albania has been inhabited by numerous civilisations such as the <a href="/wiki/Illyrians" title="Illyrians">Illyrians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">Thracians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greeks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Romans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Venetian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Venetian Empire">Venetians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottomans</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Albanians" title="Albanians">Albanians</a> established the autonomous <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Arb%C3%ABr" class="mw-redirect" title="Principality of Arbër">Principality of Arbër</a> in the 12th century. The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Albania_(medieval)" title="Kingdom of Albania (medieval)">Kingdom of Albania</a> and <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Albania_(medieval)" title="Principality of Albania (medieval)">Principality of Albania</a> formed between the 13th and 14th centuries. Prior to the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Albania" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Albania">Ottoman conquest of Albania</a> in the 15th century, the <a href="/wiki/Skanderbeg#Rebellion_against_the_Ottomans" title="Skanderbeg">Albanian resistance</a> to Ottoman expansion into Europe led by <a href="/wiki/Gjergj_Kastrioti_Skanderbeg" class="mw-redirect" title="Gjergj Kastrioti Skanderbeg">Gjergj Kastrioti Skanderbeg</a> won them acclaim over most of Europe. Between the 18th and 19th centuries, cultural developments, widely attributed to Albanians having gathered both spiritual and intellectual strength, conclusively led to the <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Renaissance" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Renaissance">Albanian Renaissance</a>. After the defeat of the Ottomans in the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Wars" title="Balkan Wars">Balkan Wars</a>, the modern <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">nation state</a> of Albania <a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_independence_of_Albania" class="mw-redirect" title="Declaration of independence of Albania">declared independence</a> in 1912.<sup id="cite_ref-cia_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-10">[7]</a></sup> In the 20th century, the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Albania_(1928%E2%80%9339)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Albania (1928–39)">Kingdom of Albania</a> was invaded by <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Italy</a> which formed <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Kingdom_(1939%E2%80%9343)" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Kingdom (1939–43)">Greater Albania</a> before becoming a <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Kingdom_(1943%E2%80%9344)" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Kingdom (1943–44)">protectorate</a> of <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[8]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Enver_Hoxha" title="Enver Hoxha">Enver Hoxha</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/People%27s_Socialist_Republic_of_Albania" title="People's Socialist Republic of Albania">People's Socialist Republic of Albania</a> after <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, modeled under the terms of <a href="/wiki/Hoxhaism" title="Hoxhaism">Hoxhaism</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1989" title="Revolutions of 1989">Revolutions of 1991</a> concluded the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_communism_in_Albania" title="Fall of communism in Albania">fall of communism in Albania</a> and eventually the establishment of the current Republic of Albania. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Albania" title="Politics of Albania">Politically</a>, Albania is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary</a> <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitutional republic">constitutional republic</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a> with an upper-middle income <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Albania" title="Economy of Albania">economy</a> dominated by the service sector, followed by manufacturing.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[9]</a></sup> It went through a process of transition following the end of communism in 1990, from <a href="/wiki/Centralized_planning" class="mw-redirect" title="Centralized planning">centralized planning</a> to a <a href="/wiki/Market-based_economy" class="mw-redirect" title="Market-based economy">market-based economy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[10]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[11]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[12]</a></sup> Albania provides <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care" title="Universal health care">universal health care</a> and free primary and secondary <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Albania" title="Education in Albania">education</a> to its citizens.<sup id="cite_ref-HDI_5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HDI-5">[5]</a></sup> Albania is a member of the United Nations, <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>, <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>, <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>, <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">COE</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">OIC</a>. It is an <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Albania_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Albania to the European Union">official candidate</a> for membership in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[13]</a></sup> It is one of the founding members of the <a href="/wiki/Energy_Community" title="Energy Community">Energy Community</a>, including the <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation</a> and <a href="/wiki/Union_for_the_Mediterranean" title="Union for the Mediterranean">Union for the Mediterranean</a>. </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style>

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_the_Albanians_and_Albania" title="Names of the Albanians and Albania">Etymology of Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The term Albania is the <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Latin" title="Medieval Latin">medieval Latin</a> name of the country. It may be derived from the <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_tribe" class="mw-redirect" title="Illyrian tribe">Illyrian tribe</a> of <a href="/wiki/Albani_(Illyrian_tribe)" class="mw-redirect" title="Albani (Illyrian tribe)">Albani</a> (<a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a>: <i lang="sq">Albanët</i>) recorded by <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a>, the geographer and astronomer from <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, who drafted a map in 150&nbsp;AD which shows the city of <a href="/wiki/Albanopolis" title="Albanopolis">Albanopolis</a> located northeast of <a href="/wiki/Durr%C3%ABs" title="Durrës">Durrës</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[15]</a></sup> The term may have a continuation in the name of a medieval settlement called <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Arbanon" title="Principality of Arbanon">Albanon</a> or Arbanon, although it is not certain that this was the same place.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[16]</a></sup> In his history written in the 10th century, the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine">Byzantine</a> historian <a href="/wiki/Michael_Attaliates" class="mw-redirect" title="Michael Attaliates">Michael Attaliates</a> was the first to refer to <a href="/wiki/Albanoi" title="Albanoi">Albanoi</a> as having taken part in a revolt against <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> in 1043 and to the Arbanitai as subjects of the Duke of <a href="/wiki/Dyrrachium" class="mw-redirect" title="Dyrrachium">Dyrrachium</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[17]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Albanians" title="Albanians">Albanians</a> called their country <i><i lang="sq" title="Albanian-language text">Arbëri or Arbëni</i></i> and referred to themselves as <i><i lang="sq" title="Albanian-language text"><a href="/wiki/Arb%C3%ABresh%C3%AB_people" title="Arbëreshë people">Arbëreshë</a> or Arbëneshë</i></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[19]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Nowadays, Albanians call their country <i><i lang="sq" title="Albanian-language text">Shqipëri or Shqipëria</i></i>. The words <i>Shqipëri</i> and <i>Shqiptar</i> are attested from 14th century onward,<sup id="cite_ref-Matasović_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Matasović-23">[20]</a></sup> but it was only at the end of 17th and beginning of the early 18th centuries that the placename <i>Shqipëria</i> and the ethnic demonym <i>Shqiptarë</i> gradually replaced <i>Arbëria</i> and <i>Arbëreshë</i> amongst <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a> speakers.<sup id="cite_ref-Matasović_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Matasović-23">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Lloshi_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lloshi-24">[21]</a></sup> The two terms are popularly interpreted as "Land of the Eagles" and "Children of the Eagles".<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[23]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Albania" title="History of Albania">History of Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Albanian_history" title="Timeline of Albanian history">Timeline of Albanian history</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory">Prehistory</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Albania" title="Prehistoric Albania">Prehistory of Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kamenic%C3%AB_Tumulus,_Albania_2018_01.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Kamenic%C3%AB_Tumulus%2C_Albania_2018_01.jpg/300px-Kamenic%C3%AB_Tumulus%2C_Albania_2018_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="87" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Kamenic%C3%AB_Tumulus%2C_Albania_2018_01.jpg/450px-Kamenic%C3%AB_Tumulus%2C_Albania_2018_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Kamenic%C3%AB_Tumulus%2C_Albania_2018_01.jpg/600px-Kamenic%C3%AB_Tumulus%2C_Albania_2018_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4120" data-file-height="1192"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kamenic%C3%AB_Tumulus,_Albania_2018_01.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The remains of <a href="/wiki/Kamenica_Tumulus" title="Kamenica Tumulus">Kamenica Tumulus</a> in the <a href="/wiki/County_of_Kor%C3%A7%C3%AB" class="mw-redirect" title="County of Korçë">county of Korçë</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The first attested traces of <a href="/wiki/Neanderthal" title="Neanderthal">neanderthal</a> presence in the territory of Albania dates back to the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Paleolithic" title="Middle Paleolithic">middle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Upper_Paleolithic" title="Upper Paleolithic">upper Paleolithic</a> period and were discovered in <a href="/wiki/Xarr%C3%AB" title="Xarrë">Xarrë</a> and at <a href="/wiki/Mount_Dajt" class="mw-redirect" title="Mount Dajt">Mount Dajt</a> in the adjacent region of <a href="/wiki/Tirana" title="Tirana">Tirana</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Prendi_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prendi-27">[24]</a></sup> Archaeological sites from this period include the <a href="/wiki/Kamenica_Tumulus" title="Kamenica Tumulus">Kamenica Tumulus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Konispol" title="Konispol">Konispol</a> Cave and <a href="/wiki/Pellumbas_Cave" class="mw-redirect" title="Pellumbas Cave">Pellumbas Cave</a>. </p>
      <p>The discovered objects in a cave near Xarrë include <a href="/wiki/Flint" title="Flint">flint</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jasper" title="Jasper">jasper</a> objects along with fossilised animal bones, while those discoveries at Mount Dajt comprise bone and stone tools similar to those of the <a href="/wiki/Aurignacian_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Aurignacian culture">Aurignacian culture</a>. They also demonstrate notable similarities with objects of the equivalent period found at Crvena Stijena in <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> and northwestern <a href="/wiki/Greece" title="Greece">Greece</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Prendi_27-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Prendi-27">[24]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Multiple artifacts from the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Ages</a> near <a href="/wiki/Tumulus" title="Tumulus">tumulus</a> burials have been unearthed in central and southern Albania, which has similar affinity with the sites in southwestern <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(region)" title="Macedonia (region)">Macedonia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lefkada" title="Lefkada">Lefkada</a>. Archaeologists have come to the conclusion that these regions were inhabited from the middle of the third millennium BC by <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_migrations" title="Indo-European migrations">Indo-European people</a> who spoke a <a href="/wiki/Proto-Greek_language" title="Proto-Greek language">Proto-Greek language</a>. Hence, a part of this historical population later moved to <a href="/wiki/Mycenae" title="Mycenae">Mycenae</a> around 1600 BC and properly established the <a href="/wiki/Mycenaean_Greece" title="Mycenaean Greece">Mycenaean civilisation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hammond1993_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hammond1993-30">[27]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Antiquity">Antiquity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Albania#Antiquity" title="History of Albania">Antiquity in Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:The_City_and_the_Prokletije_from_the_castle.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/The_City_and_the_Prokletije_from_the_castle.jpg/220px-The_City_and_the_Prokletije_from_the_castle.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="121" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/The_City_and_the_Prokletije_from_the_castle.jpg/330px-The_City_and_the_Prokletije_from_the_castle.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/The_City_and_the_Prokletije_from_the_castle.jpg/440px-The_City_and_the_Prokletije_from_the_castle.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4592" data-file-height="2520"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:The_City_and_the_Prokletije_from_the_castle.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Founded in the 4th century BC, <a href="/wiki/Scodra" class="mw-redirect" title="Scodra">Scodra</a> was a significant city of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Illyrian_tribes" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Illyrian tribes">Illyrian</a> tribes of the <a href="/wiki/Ardiaei" title="Ardiaei">Ardiaei</a> and <a href="/wiki/Labeates" class="mw-redirect" title="Labeates">Labeates</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In ancient times, the incorporated territory of Albania was historically inhabited by <a href="/wiki/Indo-European_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Indo-European people">Indo-European peoples</a>, among them numerous <a href="/wiki/Illyrians" title="Illyrians">Illyrian</a> <a href="/wiki/Illyrian_tribe" class="mw-redirect" title="Illyrian tribe">tribes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greeks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thracians" title="Thracians">Thracians</a>. In view of the Illyrian tribes, there is no evidence that these tribes used any collective nomenclature for themselves, while it is regarded to be unlikely that they used a common <a href="/wiki/Endonym" class="mw-redirect" title="Endonym">endonym</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[28]</a></sup> The endonym <i>Illyrians</i> seems to be the name applied to a specific Illyrian tribe, which was the first to come in liaison with the Ancient Greeks resulting the endonym <i>Illyrians</i> to be applied <i><a href="/wiki/Pars_pro_toto" title="Pars pro toto">pars pro toto</a></i> to all people of similar language and customs.<sup id="cite_ref-Boardman629_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boardman629-32">[29]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[30]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Parku_Arkeologjik_i_Apollonis%C3%AB_04.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Parku_Arkeologjik_i_Apollonis%C3%AB_04.jpg/220px-Parku_Arkeologjik_i_Apollonis%C3%AB_04.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Parku_Arkeologjik_i_Apollonis%C3%AB_04.jpg/330px-Parku_Arkeologjik_i_Apollonis%C3%AB_04.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/Parku_Arkeologjik_i_Apollonis%C3%AB_04.jpg/440px-Parku_Arkeologjik_i_Apollonis%C3%AB_04.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4016" data-file-height="2745"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Parku_Arkeologjik_i_Apollonis%C3%AB_04.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Apollonia_(Illyria)" title="Apollonia (Illyria)">Apollonia</a> was an important <a href="/wiki/Colonies_in_antiquity#Greek_colonies" title="Colonies in antiquity">Ancient Greek colony</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Illyria" title="Illyria">Illyrian</a> coast along the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic Sea</a> and one of the western points of the <a href="/wiki/Via_Egnatia" title="Via Egnatia">Via Egnatia</a> route, that connected Rome and <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The territory referred to as <a href="/wiki/Illyria" title="Illyria">Illyria</a> corresponded roughly to the area east of the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic Sea</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> extending in the south to the mouth of the <a href="/wiki/Vjos%C3%AB" class="mw-redirect" title="Vjosë">Vjosë</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[32]</a></sup> The first account of the Illyrian groups comes from <a href="/wiki/Periplus_of_the_Euxine_Sea" title="Periplus of the Euxine Sea">Periplus of the Euxine Sea</a>, an ancient Greek text written in the middle of the 4th century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-wilkes_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wilkes-36">[33]</a></sup> The west was inhabited by the Thracian tribe of the <a href="/wiki/Bryges" title="Bryges">Bryges</a> while the south was inhabited by the Ancient Greek-speaking tribe of the <a href="/wiki/Chaonians" title="Chaonians">Chaonians</a>, whose capital was at <a href="/wiki/Phoenice" title="Phoenice">Phoenice</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-wilkes_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wilkes-36">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[35]</a></sup> Other colonies such as <a href="/wiki/Apollonia_(Illyria)" title="Apollonia (Illyria)">Apollonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epidamnos" title="Epidamnos">Epidamnos</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amantia" title="Amantia">Amantia</a>, were established by Ancient Greek city-states on the coast by the 7th century BC.<sup id="cite_ref-wilkes_36-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wilkes-36">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[36]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[37]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Illyrian <a href="/wiki/Ardiaei" title="Ardiaei">Ardiaei</a> tribe, centered in Montenegro, ruled over most of the territory of Albania. Their <a href="/wiki/Ardiaean_Kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Ardiaean Kingdom">Ardiaean Kingdom</a> reached its greatest extent under <a href="/wiki/Agron_of_Illyria" title="Agron of Illyria">King Agron</a>, the son of <a href="/wiki/Pleuratus_II" title="Pleuratus II">Pleuratus II</a>. Agron extended his rule over other neighboring tribes as well.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[38]</a></sup> Following Agron's death in 230 BC, his wife, <a href="/wiki/Teuta" title="Teuta">Teuta</a>, inherited the&nbsp;Ardiaean kingdom. Teuta's forces extended their operations further southward to the&nbsp;Ionian Sea.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[39]</a></sup> In 229 BC, Rome declared war<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[40]</a></sup> on the kingdom for extensively plundering Roman ships. The war ended in Illyrian defeat in 227&nbsp;BC. Teuta was eventually succeeded by&nbsp;<a href="/wiki/Gentius" title="Gentius">Gentius</a>&nbsp;in 181&nbsp;BC.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[41]</a></sup> Gentius clashed with the Romans in 168&nbsp;BC, initiating the <a href="/wiki/Third_Illyrian_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Third Illyrian War">Third Illyrian War</a>. The conflict resulted in Roman conquest of the region by 167&nbsp;BC. The Romans split the region into three administrative divisions.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[42]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Albania_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Albania in the Middle Ages">Albania in the Middle Ages</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Kruj%C3%AB-KrujaAlbania_2016.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Kruj%C3%AB-KrujaAlbania_2016.jpg/220px-Kruj%C3%AB-KrujaAlbania_2016.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Kruj%C3%AB-KrujaAlbania_2016.jpg/330px-Kruj%C3%AB-KrujaAlbania_2016.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/43/Kruj%C3%AB-KrujaAlbania_2016.jpg/440px-Kruj%C3%AB-KrujaAlbania_2016.jpg 2x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Kruj%C3%AB-KrujaAlbania_2016.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The town of <a href="/wiki/Kruj%C3%AB" title="Krujë">Krujë</a> was the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Arbanon" title="Principality of Arbanon">Principality of Arbanon</a> in the Middle Ages.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a> was split in 395 upon the death of <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_I" title="Theodosius I">Theodosius I</a> into an <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Roman Empire">Eastern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Roman Empire</a> in part because of the increasing pressure from threats during the <a href="/wiki/Barbarian_Invasions" class="mw-redirect" title="Barbarian Invasions">Barbarian Invasions</a>. From the 6th century into the 7th century, the <a href="/wiki/South_Slavs" title="South Slavs">Slavs</a> crossed the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> and largely absorbed the indigenous Ancient Greeks, Illyrians and Thracians in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>; thus, the Illyrians were mentioned for the last time in historical records in the 7th century.<sup id="cite_ref-BideleuxJeffries2007_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BideleuxJeffries2007-46">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Schaefer2008_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Schaefer2008-47">[44]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the 11th century, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Schism_of_1054" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Schism of 1054">Great Schism</a> formalised the break of communion between the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Orthodox_Church" title="Eastern Orthodox Church">Eastern Orthodox</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Catholic_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Catholic Church">Western Catholic Church</a> that is reflected in Albania through the emergence of a Catholic north and Orthodox south. The Albanian people inhabited the west of <a href="/wiki/Lake_Ochrida" class="mw-redirect" title="Lake Ochrida">Lake Ochrida</a> and the upper valley of <a href="/wiki/Shkumbin" title="Shkumbin">River Shkumbin</a> and established the <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Arbanon" title="Principality of Arbanon">Principality of Arbanon</a> in 1190 under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Progon_of_Kruja" class="mw-redirect" title="Progon of Kruja">Progon of Kruja</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[45]</a></sup> The realm was succeeded by his sons <a href="/wiki/Gjin_Progoni" title="Gjin Progoni">Gjin</a> and Dhimitri. </p>
      <p>Upon the death of Dhimiter, the territory came under the rule of the Albanian-Greek <a href="/wiki/Gregory_Kamonas" class="mw-redirect" title="Gregory Kamonas">Gregory Kamonas</a> and subsequently under the <a href="/wiki/Golem_of_Kruja" title="Golem of Kruja">Golem of Kruja</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Abulafia_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abulafia-50">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Genealogist_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Genealogist-51">[48]</a></sup> In the 13th century, the principality was dissolved.<sup id="cite_ref-Clements31_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Clements31-52">[49]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-PickardÇeliku2008_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PickardÇeliku2008-53">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Norris1993_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Norris1993-54">[51]</a></sup> Arbanon is considered to be the first sketch of an Albanian state, that retained a <a href="/wiki/Semi-autonomous" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-autonomous">semi-autonomous</a> status as the western extremity of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, under the Byzantine <a href="/wiki/Doukas" title="Doukas">Doukai</a> of <a href="/wiki/Despotate_of_Epirus" title="Despotate of Epirus">Epirus</a> or <a href="/wiki/Laskaris" title="Laskaris">Laskarids</a> of <a href="/wiki/Empire_of_Nicaea" title="Empire of Nicaea">Nicaea</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[52]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venezia_-_Ex_Scola_degli_albanesi_(sec._XV)_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto,_12-Aug-2007_-_11_-_Maometto_II_assedia_Scutari.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Venezia_-_Ex_Scola_degli_albanesi_%28sec._XV%29_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_12-Aug-2007_-_11_-_Maometto_II_assedia_Scutari.jpg/220px-Venezia_-_Ex_Scola_degli_albanesi_%28sec._XV%29_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_12-Aug-2007_-_11_-_Maometto_II_assedia_Scutari.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Venezia_-_Ex_Scola_degli_albanesi_%28sec._XV%29_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_12-Aug-2007_-_11_-_Maometto_II_assedia_Scutari.jpg/330px-Venezia_-_Ex_Scola_degli_albanesi_%28sec._XV%29_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_12-Aug-2007_-_11_-_Maometto_II_assedia_Scutari.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d1/Venezia_-_Ex_Scola_degli_albanesi_%28sec._XV%29_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_12-Aug-2007_-_11_-_Maometto_II_assedia_Scutari.jpg/440px-Venezia_-_Ex_Scola_degli_albanesi_%28sec._XV%29_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto%2C_12-Aug-2007_-_11_-_Maometto_II_assedia_Scutari.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venezia_-_Ex_Scola_degli_albanesi_(sec._XV)_-_Foto_Giovanni_Dall%27Orto,_12-Aug-2007_-_11_-_Maometto_II_assedia_Scutari.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>A relief of the <a href="/wiki/Scuola_degli_Albanesi" title="Scuola degli Albanesi">Scuola degli Albanesi</a> commemorating the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Shkodra" title="Siege of Shkodra">Siege of Shkodra</a>. It illustrates <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Sultan" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Sultan">Sultan</a> <a href="/wiki/Mehmet_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Mehmet II">Mehmet II</a> laying siege to the Albanian town of Scutari then part of <a href="/wiki/Venetian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Venetian Empire">Venetian Empire</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Towards the end of the 12th and beginning of the 13th centuries, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia_(medieval)" title="Kingdom of Serbia (medieval)">Serbs</a> and <a href="/wiki/Venetian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Venetian Empire">Venetians</a> started to take possession over the territory.<sup id="cite_ref-Barbarian_Invasions_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barbarian_Invasions-56">[53]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ethnogenesis" title="Ethnogenesis">ethnogenesis</a> of the Albanians is uncertain; however the first undisputed mention of Albanians dates back in historical records from 1079 or 1080 in a work by <a href="/wiki/Michael_Attaliates" class="mw-redirect" title="Michael Attaliates">Michael Attaliates</a>, who referred to the <a href="/wiki/Albanoi" title="Albanoi">Albanoi</a> as having taken part in a revolt against <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[54]</a></sup> At this point the Albanians were fully Christianized. </p>
      <p>Few years after the dissolution of Arbanon, <a href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_Naples" class="mw-redirect" title="Charles I of Naples">Charles of Anjou</a> concluded an agreement with the Albanian rulers, promising to protect them and their ancient liberties. In 1272, he established the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Albania_(medieval)" title="Kingdom of Albania (medieval)">Kingdom of Albania</a> and conquered regions back from the <a href="/wiki/Despotate_of_Epirus" title="Despotate of Epirus">Despotate of Epirus</a>. The kingdom claimed all of central Albania territory from <a href="/wiki/Dyrrhachium" class="mw-redirect" title="Dyrrhachium">Dyrrhachium</a> along the Adriatic Sea coast down to <a href="/wiki/Butrint" title="Butrint">Butrint</a>. A catholic political structure was a basis for the papal plans of spreading <a href="/wiki/Catholicism" class="mw-redirect" title="Catholicism">Catholicism</a> in the Balkan Peninsula. This plan found also the support of <a href="/wiki/Helen_of_Anjou" title="Helen of Anjou">Helen of Anjou</a>, a cousin of Charles of Anjou. Around 30 Catholic churches and monasteries were built during her rule mainly in northern Albania.<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[55]</a></sup> Internal power struggles within the Byzantine Empire in the 14th century enabled Serbs' most powerful medieval ruler, <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Dusan" class="mw-redirect" title="Stefan Dusan">Stefan Dusan</a>, to establish a <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Empire" title="Serbian Empire">short-lived empire</a> that included all of Albania except Durrës.<sup id="cite_ref-Barbarian_Invasions_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barbarian_Invasions-56">[53]</a></sup> In 1367, various Albanian rulers established the <a href="/wiki/Despotate_of_Arta" title="Despotate of Arta">Despotate of Arta</a>. During that time, several <a href="/wiki/Albanian_principalities" title="Albanian principalities">Albanian principalities</a> were created, notably the <a href="/wiki/Balsha" class="mw-redirect" title="Balsha">Balsha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thopia_family" title="Thopia family">Thopia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kastrioti_Principality" class="mw-redirect" title="Kastrioti Principality">Kastrioti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muzaka_family" title="Muzaka family">Muzaka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arianiti_family" title="Arianiti family">Arianiti</a>. In the first half of the 15th century, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> invaded most of Albania, and the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Lezh%C3%AB" title="League of Lezhë">League of Lezhë</a> was held under <a href="/wiki/Skanderbeg" title="Skanderbeg">Skanderbeg</a> as a ruler, who became the national hero of the Albanian medieval history. </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_Empire">Ottoman Empire</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Albania_under_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Albania under the Ottoman Empire">Albania under the Ottoman Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Skanderbeg#Rebellion_against_the_Ottomans" title="Skanderbeg">Albanian rebellion against the Ottoman Empire</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/League_of_Lezh%C3%AB" title="League of Lezhë">League of Lezhë</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Skanderbeg_by_Antonio_Maria_Crespi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Skanderbeg_by_Antonio_Maria_Crespi.jpg/170px-Skanderbeg_by_Antonio_Maria_Crespi.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="199" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Skanderbeg_by_Antonio_Maria_Crespi.jpg/255px-Skanderbeg_by_Antonio_Maria_Crespi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Skanderbeg_by_Antonio_Maria_Crespi.jpg/340px-Skanderbeg_by_Antonio_Maria_Crespi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="936"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Skanderbeg_by_Antonio_Maria_Crespi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>After serving the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> for nearly 20 years, <a href="/wiki/Gjergj_Kastrioti_Skanderbeg" class="mw-redirect" title="Gjergj Kastrioti Skanderbeg">Gjergj Kastrioti Skanderbeg</a> deserted and began a <a href="/wiki/Skanderbeg%27s_rebellion" title="Skanderbeg's rebellion">rebellion against the empire</a> that halted Ottoman advance into Europe for 25 years.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>With the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_Constantinople" title="Fall of Constantinople">fall of Constantinople</a>, the Ottoman Empire continued an extended period of conquest and expansion with its borders going deep into <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_conquest_of_the_Balkans" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman conquest of the Balkans">Southeast Europe</a>. They reached the <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Ionian_Sea_Coast" title="Albanian Ionian Sea Coast">Albanian Ionian Sea Coast</a> in 1385 and erected their garrisons across <a href="/wiki/Southern_Albania" title="Southern Albania">Southern Albania</a> in 1415 and then occupied most of Albania in 1431.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[56]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Hupchich110_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hupchich110-60">[57]</a></sup> Thousands of Albanians consequently fled to Western Europe, particularly to <a href="/wiki/Calabria" title="Calabria">Calabria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Naples" title="Kingdom of Naples">Naples</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa" title="Republic of Ragusa">Ragusa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Sicily" title="Kingdom of Sicily">Sicily</a>, whereby others sought protection at the often inaccessible <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Albania" title="Geography of Albania">Mountains of Albania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[59]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Albanians, as Christians, were considered as an <a href="/wiki/Rayah" title="Rayah">inferior class</a> of people, and as such they were subjected to heavy <a href="/wiki/Jizya" title="Jizya">taxes</a> among others by the <a href="/wiki/Devshirme" title="Devshirme">Devshirme</a> system that allowed the <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">Sultan</a> to collect a requisite percentage of Christian adolescents from their families to compose the <a href="/wiki/Janissary" title="Janissary">Janissary</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[60]</a></sup> The Ottoman conquest was also accompanied with the gradual process of <a href="/wiki/Islamisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Islamisation">Islamisation</a> and the rapid construction of mosques which consequently modified the religious picture of Albania. </p>
      <p>A prosperous and longstanding revolution erupted after the formation of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Lezh%C3%AB" title="League of Lezhë">Assembly of Lezhë</a> until the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Shkodra" title="Siege of Shkodra">Siege of Shkodër</a> under the leadership of <a href="/wiki/Gjergj_Kastrioti_Skanderbeg" class="mw-redirect" title="Gjergj Kastrioti Skanderbeg">Gjergj Kastrioti Skanderbeg</a>, multiple times defeating major Ottoman armies led by <a href="/wiki/Sultan" title="Sultan">Sultans</a> <a href="/wiki/Murad_II" title="Murad II">Murad II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_II" class="mw-redirect" title="Mehmed II">Mehmed II</a>. Skanderbeg managed to gather several of the Albanian principals, amongst them the <a href="/wiki/Arianiti_family" title="Arianiti family">Arianitis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dukagjini_family" title="Dukagjini family">Dukagjinis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zaharia_family" title="Zaharia family">Zaharias</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thopia_family" title="Thopia family">Thopias</a>, and establish a centralised authority over most of the non-conquered territories, becoming the <a href="/wiki/Skanderbeg" title="Skanderbeg">Lord of Albania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-League_of_Lezhë_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-League_of_Lezhë-64">[61]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Skanderbeg consistently pursued the goal relentlessly but rather unsuccessfully to constitute a European coalition against the Ottomans. He thwarted every attempt by the Ottomans to regain Albania, which they envisioned as a springboard for the invasion of Italy and Western Europe. His unequal fight against them won the esteem of Europe also among others financial and military aid from the <a href="/wiki/Papacy" class="mw-redirect" title="Papacy">Papacy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Naples" title="Kingdom of Naples">Naples</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Venice</a> and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Ragusa" title="Republic of Ragusa">Ragusa</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-britannica_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-65">[62]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venturas1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Venturas1.jpg/175px-Venturas1.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="203" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Venturas1.jpg/263px-Venturas1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Venturas1.jpg/350px-Venturas1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="663" data-file-height="768"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venturas1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ali_Pasha_of_Ioannina" title="Ali Pasha of Ioannina">Ali Pasha Tepelena</a> was a powerful autonomous Ottoman Albanian ruler who governed over the <a href="/wiki/Pashalik_of_Yanina" title="Pashalik of Yanina">Pashalik of Yanina</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>When the Ottomans were gaining a firm foothold in the region, Albanian towns were organised into four principal <a href="/wiki/Sanjaks" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanjaks">sanjaks</a>. The government fostered trade by settling a sizeable Jewish colony of refugees fleeing persecution in Spain. The city of <a href="/wiki/Vlor%C3%AB" title="Vlorë">Vlorë</a> saw passing through its ports imported merchandise from Europe such as velvets, cotton goods, mohairs, carpets, spices and leather from <a href="/wiki/Bursa" title="Bursa">Bursa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>. Some citizens of Vlorë even had business associates throughout Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-Arnawutlu_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arnawutlu-66">[63]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The phenomenon of Islamisation among the Albanians became primarily widespread from the 17th century and continued into the 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-referenceworks.brillonline_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-referenceworks.brillonline-67">[64]</a></sup> Islam offered them equal opportunities and advancement within the Ottoman Empire. However, motives for conversion were, according to some scholars, diverse depending on the context though the lack of source material does not help when investigating such issues.<sup id="cite_ref-referenceworks.brillonline_67-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-referenceworks.brillonline-67">[64]</a></sup> Because of increasing suppression of Catholicism, mostly catholic Albanians converted in the 17th century, while orthodox Albanians followed suit mainly in the following century. </p>
      <p>Since the Albanians were seen as strategically important, they made up a significant proportion of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_military" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman military">Ottoman military</a> and bureaucracy. A couple of Muslim Albanians attained important political and military positions who culturally contributed to the broader <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-referenceworks.brillonline_67-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-referenceworks.brillonline-67">[64]</a></sup> Enjoying this privileged position, they held various high administrative positions with over two dozen Albanian <a href="/wiki/Grand_Viziers" class="mw-redirect" title="Grand Viziers">Grand Viziers</a> among others members of the prominent <a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6pr%C3%BCl%C3%BC_family" title="Köprülü family">Köprülü family</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zagan_Pasha" title="Zagan Pasha">Zagan Pasha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt" title="Muhammad Ali of Egypt">Muhammad Ali of Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ali_Pasha_of_Tepelena" class="mw-redirect" title="Ali Pasha of Tepelena">Ali Pasha of Tepelena</a> however, two sultans such as <a href="/wiki/Bayezid_II" title="Bayezid II">Bayezid II</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mehmed_III" title="Mehmed III">Mehmed III</a> had both mothers of Albanian origin.<sup id="cite_ref-Arnawutlu_66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arnawutlu-66">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[65]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[66]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rilindja">Rilindja</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Renaissance" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Renaissance">Albanian Renaissance</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/League_of_Prizren" title="League of Prizren">League of Prizren</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:NaumVeqilharxhi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/NaumVeqilharxhi.jpg/170px-NaumVeqilharxhi.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="239" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/NaumVeqilharxhi.jpg/255px-NaumVeqilharxhi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/NaumVeqilharxhi.jpg/340px-NaumVeqilharxhi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="689" data-file-height="967"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:NaumVeqilharxhi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Naum_Veqilharxhi" title="Naum Veqilharxhi">Naum Veqilharxhi</a> was among the most important figures of the early <a href="/wiki/Albanian_National_Awakening" title="Albanian National Awakening">National Renaissance</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Renaissance" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Renaissance">Albanian Renaissance</a> was a period with its roots in the late 18th century and continuing into the 19th century, during which the Albanian people gathered spiritual and intellectual strength for an independent cultural and political life within an <a href="/wiki/Independent_Albania" title="Independent Albania">independent nation</a>. Modern <a href="/wiki/Albanian_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian culture">Albanian culture</a> flourished too, especially <a href="/wiki/Albanian_literature" title="Albanian literature">Albanian literature</a> and <a href="/wiki/Albanian_art" title="Albanian art">arts</a>, and was frequently linked to the influences of the <a href="/wiki/Romanticism" title="Romanticism">Romanticism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> principles.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[67]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Prior to the <a href="/wiki/Rise_of_nationalism_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Rise of nationalism in the Ottoman Empire">rise of nationalism</a>, Albania was under the rule of the Ottoman Empire for almost five centuries, and Ottoman authorities suppressed any expression of national unity or conscience by the Albanian people. Through literature, Albanians started to make a conscious effort to awaken feelings of pride and unity among their people that would call to mind the rich history and hopes for a more decent future. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dora_d%27Istria_(drawing).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Dora_d%27Istria_%28drawing%29.jpg/170px-Dora_d%27Istria_%28drawing%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="234" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Dora_d%27Istria_%28drawing%29.jpg/255px-Dora_d%27Istria_%28drawing%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Dora_d%27Istria_%28drawing%29.jpg/340px-Dora_d%27Istria_%28drawing%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="505" data-file-height="694"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dora_d%27Istria_(drawing).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Dora_d%27Istria" title="Dora d'Istria">Dora d'Istria</a> was among the main advocates in Europe for the <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Renaissance" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Renaissance">Albanian cause</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[68]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The victory of Russia over the Ottoman Empire following the <a href="/wiki/Russian-Ottoman_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian-Ottoman War">Russian-Ottoman Wars</a> resulted the execution of the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Stefano" title="Treaty of San Stefano">Treaty of San Stefano</a> which overlooked to assign Albanian-populated lands to the Slavic and Greek neighbours. However, the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">United Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Austro-Hungarian Empire">Austro-Hungarian Empire</a> consequently blocked the arrangement and caused the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Berlin_(1878)" title="Treaty of Berlin (1878)">Treaty of Berlin</a>. From this point, Albanians started to organise themselves with the goal to protect and unite the Albanian-populated lands into a unitary nation, leading to the formation of the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Prizren" title="League of Prizren">League of Prizren</a>. </p>
      <p>The league had initially the assistance of the Ottoman authorities whose position was based on the religious solidarity of Muslim people and landlords connected with the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Porte" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman Porte">Ottoman administration</a>. They favoured and protected the Muslim solidarity and called for defense of Muslim lands simultaneously constituting the reason for titling the league <a href="/wiki/League_of_Prizren#Formation" title="League of Prizren">Committee of the Real Muslims</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[69]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Approximately 300 Muslims participated in the assembly composed by delegates from Bosnia, the <a href="/wiki/Sanjakbey" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanjakbey">administrator</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Sanjak_of_Prizren" title="Sanjak of Prizren">Sanjak of Prizren</a> as representatives of the central authorities and no delegates from <a href="/wiki/Vilayet_of_Scutari" class="mw-redirect" title="Vilayet of Scutari">Vilayet of Scutari</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[70]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style#Punctuation" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style"><span title="Quotation marks may be incomplete, unbalanced or improperly applied.">check quotation syntax</span></a></i>]</sup> Signed by only 47 Muslim deputies, the league issued the <a href="/wiki/Kararname_(League_of_Prizren)" title="Kararname (League of Prizren)">Kararname</a> that contained a proclamation that the people from northern Albania, <a href="/wiki/Epirus" title="Epirus">Epirus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> are willing to defend the <a href="/wiki/Territorial_integrity" title="Territorial integrity">territorial integrity</a> of the Ottoman Empire by all possible means against the troops of <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Bulgaria" title="Kingdom of Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Montenegro" title="Kingdom of Montenegro">Montenegro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-albanianhistory.net_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-albanianhistory.net-74">[71]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ottomans authorities cancelled their assistance when the league, under <a href="/wiki/Abdyl_Frash%C3%ABri" title="Abdyl Frashëri">Abdyl Frashëri</a>, became focused on working toward Albanian autonomy and requested merging four <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_vilayet" class="mw-redirect" title="Ottoman vilayet">vilayets</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Vilayet" title="Kosovo Vilayet">Kosovo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Scutari_Vilayet" title="Scutari Vilayet">Shkodër</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monastir_Vilayet" class="mw-redirect" title="Monastir Vilayet">Monastir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Janina_Vilayet" title="Janina Vilayet">Ioannina</a>, into an unified vilayet, the <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Vilayet" title="Albanian Vilayet">Albanian Vilayet</a>. The league used military force to prevent the annexing areas of <a href="/wiki/Plav_Municipality" title="Plav Municipality">Plav</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gusinje" title="Gusinje">Gusinje</a> assigned to Montenegro. After several successful battles with Montenegrin troops, such as the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Nov%C5%A1i%C4%87e" title="Battle of Novšiće">Battle of Novšiće</a>, the league was forced to retreat from their contested regions. The league was later defeated by the Ottoman army sent by the sultan.<sup id="cite_ref-League_of_Prizren_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-League_of_Prizren-75">[72]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Independence">Independence</span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Independent_Albania" title="Independent Albania">Independent Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Albanian Declaration of Independence">Albanian Declaration of Independence</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Ismail_Qemali_(portrait).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ismail_Qemali_%28portrait%29.jpg/175px-Ismail_Qemali_%28portrait%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="234" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ismail_Qemali_%28portrait%29.jpg/263px-Ismail_Qemali_%28portrait%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Ismail_Qemali_%28portrait%29.jpg/350px-Ismail_Qemali_%28portrait%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="457" data-file-height="611"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Ismail_Qemali_(portrait).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ismail_Qemali" title="Ismail Qemali">Ismail Qemali</a> is regarded as the <a href="/wiki/List_of_national_founders#Albania" title="List of national founders">founding father</a> of the modern Albanian nation.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Albania <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Declaration_of_Independence" title="Albanian Declaration of Independence">declared independence</a> from the Ottoman Empire on 28 November 1912, accompanied with the establishment of the <a href="/wiki/Senate_of_Albania" class="mw-redirect" title="Senate of Albania">Senate</a> and <a href="/wiki/Provisional_Government_of_Albania" title="Provisional Government of Albania">Government</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Assembly_of_Vlor%C3%AB" title="Assembly of Vlorë">Assembly of Vlorë</a> on 4 December 1912.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[73]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[74]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[76]</a></sup> Its sovereignty was recognised by the <a href="/wiki/London_Conference_of_1912%E2%80%931913" title="London Conference of 1912–1913">Conference of London</a>. On 29 July 1913, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London_(1913)" title="Treaty of London (1913)">Treaty of London</a> delineated the borders of the country and its neighbors, leaving many Albanians outside Albania, predominantly <a href="/wiki/Partition_(politics)" title="Partition (politics)">partitioned</a> between <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Montenegro" title="Kingdom of Montenegro">Montenegro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece" title="Kingdom of Greece">Greece</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[77]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Headquartered in Vlorë, the <a href="/wiki/International_Commission_of_Control" class="mw-redirect" title="International Commission of Control">International Commission of Control</a> was established on 15 October 1913 to take care of the administration of newly established Albania, until its own political institutions were in order.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[78]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[79]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/International_Gendarmerie" title="International Gendarmerie">International Gendarmerie</a> was established as the first law enforcement agency of the <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Albania" title="Principality of Albania">Principality of Albania</a>. In November, the first gendarmerie members arrived in the country. Prince of Albania <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_of_Wied" class="mw-redirect" title="Wilhelm of Wied">Wilhelm of Wied</a> <i>(Princ Vilhelm Vidi)</i> was selected as the first prince of the principality.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[80]</a></sup> On 7 March, he arrived in the provisional capital of <a href="/wiki/Durr%C3%ABs" title="Durrës">Durrës</a> and started to organise his government, appointing <a href="/wiki/Turhan_Pasha_P%C3%ABrmeti" title="Turhan Pasha Përmeti">Turhan Pasha Përmeti</a> to form the first Albanian cabinet. </p>
      <p>In November 1913, the Albanian pro-Ottoman forces had offered the throne of Albania to the Ottoman war Minister of Albanian origin, <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Izzet_Pasha" title="Ahmed Izzet Pasha">Ahmed Izzet Pasha</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[81]</a></sup> The pro-Ottoman peasants believed that the new regime was a tool of the six Christian <a href="/wiki/Great_Power" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Power">Great Powers</a> and local landowners, that owned half of the arable land.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[82]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In February 1914, the <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Republic_of_Northern_Epirus" title="Autonomous Republic of Northern Epirus">Autonomous Republic of Northern Epirus</a> was proclaimed in <a href="/wiki/Gjirokast%C3%ABr" title="Gjirokastër">Gjirokastër</a> by the local <a href="/wiki/Greeks_in_Albania" title="Greeks in Albania">Greek population</a> against incorporation to Albania. This initiative was short lived, and in 1921 the southern provinces were incorporated into the Albanian Principality.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[83]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[84]</a></sup> Meanwhile, the <a href="/wiki/Peasant_Revolt_in_Albania" title="Peasant Revolt in Albania">revolt of Albanian peasants</a> against the new Albanian regime erupted under the leadership of the group of Muslim clerics gathered around <a href="/wiki/Essad_Pasha_Toptani" title="Essad Pasha Toptani">Essad Pasha Toptani</a>, who proclaimed himself the savior of Albania and Islam.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[85]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[86]</a></sup> In order to gain support of the <a href="/wiki/Mirdita" title="Mirdita">Mirdita</a> Catholic volunteers from the northern part of Albania, Prince <a href="/wiki/Wilhelm_of_Wied" class="mw-redirect" title="Wilhelm of Wied">Wied</a> appointed their leader, <a href="/wiki/Pr%C3%AAnk_Bib%C3%AB_Doda" class="mw-redirect" title="Prênk Bibë Doda">Prênk Bibë Doda</a>, to be the foreign minister of the Principality of Albania. In May and June 1914, the International Gendarmerie was joined by <a href="/wiki/Isa_Boletini" title="Isa Boletini">Isa Boletini</a> and his men, mostly from <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[87]</a></sup> and northern <a href="/wiki/Mirdita" title="Mirdita">Mirdita</a> Catholics, were defeated by the rebels who captured most of Central Albania by the end of August 1914.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[88]</a></sup> The regime of Prince Wied collapsed, and he left the country on 3 September 1914.<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[89]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_Republic">First Republic</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Republic">First Republic of Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_in_Albania" title="World War II in Albania">World War II in Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Albania" title="The Holocaust in Albania">The Holocaust in Albania</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Albanian_Righteous_Among_the_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Albanian Righteous Among the Nations">Albanian Righteous Among the Nations</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:177px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:King_Zog.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/King_Zog.jpg/175px-King_Zog.jpg" decoding="async" width="175" height="236" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/King_Zog.jpg/263px-King_Zog.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/King_Zog.jpg/350px-King_Zog.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3820" data-file-height="5158"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:King_Zog.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Zog_I_of_Albania" title="Zog I of Albania">Zog I</a> was the first and only king of Albania; his reign lasted 11 years (1928–1939).
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the end of the government of <a href="/wiki/Fan_Noli" title="Fan Noli">Fan Noli</a>, the parliament adopted a new constitution and proclaimed the country as a parliamentary republic in which King <a href="/wiki/Zog_I_of_Albania" title="Zog I of Albania">Zog I of Albania</a> (Ahmet Muhtar Zogu) served as the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a> for a seven-year term. Immediately after, <a href="/wiki/Tirana" title="Tirana">Tirana</a> was endorsed officially as the country's permanent capital.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[90]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The politics of Zogu was authoritarian and conservative with the primary aim of the maintenance of stability and order. He was forced to adopt a policy of cooperation with Italy where a pact had been signed between both countries, whereby Italy gained a monopoly on shipping and trade concessions.<sup id="cite_ref-Vickers_94-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vickers-94">[91]</a></sup> Italians exercised control over nearly every Albanian official through money and patronage.<sup id="cite_ref-Gerwarth_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gerwarth-95">[92]</a></sup> In 1928, the country was eventually replaced by <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Albania_(1928%E2%80%931939)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Albania (1928–1939)">another monarchy</a> with a strong support by the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Fascism" title="Italian Fascism">fascist regime</a> of Italy however, both maintained close relations until the <a href="/wiki/Italian_invasion_of_Albania" title="Italian invasion of Albania">Italian invasion</a> of the country. Zogu remained a conservative but initiated reforms and placed great emphasis on the development of infrastructure. </p>
      <p>In an attempt at social modernisation, the custom of adding one's region to one's name was dropped. He also made donations of land to international organisations for the building of schools and hospitals. The armed forces were trained and supervised by instructors from Italy, and as a counterweight, he kept British officers in the <a href="/wiki/Gendarmerie" title="Gendarmerie">Gendarmerie</a> despite strong Italian pressure to remove them. </p>
      <p>After being militarily occupied by Italy from 1939 until 1943, the <a href="/wiki/Albanian_Kingdom_(1939%E2%80%9343)" class="mw-redirect" title="Albanian Kingdom (1939–43)">Kingdom of Albania</a> was a <a href="/wiki/Protectorate" title="Protectorate">protectorate</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Dependent_territory" title="Dependent territory">dependency</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Italy" title="Kingdom of Italy">Kingdom of Italy</a> governed by <a href="/wiki/Victor_Emmanuel_III_of_Italy" title="Victor Emmanuel III of Italy">Victor Emmanuel III</a> and his government. In October 1940, Albania served as a staging ground for an unsuccessful Italian <a href="/wiki/Greco-Italian_War" title="Greco-Italian War">invasion of Greece</a>. A counterattack resulted in a sizeable portion of southern Albania coming under Greek military control until April 1941 when Greece capitulated during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Greece" title="Battle of Greece">German invasion</a>. In April 1941, territories of <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a> with substantial Albanian population were annexed to Albania inclusively western Macedonia, a strip of eastern Montenegro, the town of <a href="/wiki/Tutin,_Serbia" title="Tutin, Serbia">Tutin</a> in central Serbia and most of Kosovo<span style="font-size:85%;"><sup id="cite_ref-status_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-status-9">[c]</a></sup></span>.<sup id="cite_ref-BogdaniLoughlin2007_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BogdaniLoughlin2007-96">[93]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Germans started to occupy the country in September 1943 and subsequently announced that they would recognise the independence of a neutral Albania and set about organising a new government, military and law enforcement. <a href="/wiki/Balli_Komb%C3%ABtar" title="Balli Kombëtar">Balli Kombëtar</a>, which had fought against Italy, formed a neutral government and side by side with the Germans fought against the communist-led <a href="/wiki/National_Liberation_Movement_(Albania)" title="National Liberation Movement (Albania)">National Liberation Movement</a> of Albania.<sup id="cite_ref-Morrock2010_97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Morrock2010-97">[94]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the last years of the war, the country fell into a civil war-like state between the communists and nationalists. The communists defeated the last anti-communist forces in the south in 1944. Before the end of November, the main German troops had withdrawn from Tirana, and the communists took control by attacking it. The partisans entirely liberated the country from German occupation on 29 November 1944. A provisional government, which the communists had formed at&nbsp;Berat&nbsp;in October, administered Albania with <a href="/wiki/Enver_Hoxha" title="Enver Hoxha">Enver Hoxha</a> as the head of government. </p>
      <p>By the end of the <a href="/wiki/Second_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Second World War">Second World War</a>, the main military and political force of the nation, the Communist party sent forces to northern Albania against the nationalists to eliminate its rivals. They faced open resistance in <a href="/wiki/Nikaj-M%C3%ABrtur" title="Nikaj-Mërtur">Nikaj-Mërtur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dukagjin_highlands" title="Dukagjin highlands">Dukagjin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kelmendi_(tribe)" title="Kelmendi (tribe)">Kelmend</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Prek_Cali" title="Prek Cali">Prek Cali</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> On 15 January 1945, a clash took place between partisans of the first Brigade and nationalist forces at the Tamara Bridge, resulting in the defeat of the nationalist forces. About 150 <a href="/wiki/Kelmendi_(tribe)" title="Kelmendi (tribe)">Kelmendi</a><sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[95]</a></sup> people were killed or tortured. This event was the starting point of many other issues which took place during <a href="/wiki/Enver_Hoxha" title="Enver Hoxha">Enver Hoxha</a>'s dictatorship. <a href="/wiki/Class_conflict" title="Class conflict">Class struggle</a> was strictly applied, human freedom and human rights were denied.<sup id="cite_ref-Albanian_Nationalism_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Albanian_Nationalism-99">[96]</a></sup> The Kelmend region was almost isolated by both the border and by a lack of roads for another 20 years, the institution of <a href="/wiki/Agricultural_cooperative" title="Agricultural cooperative">agricultural cooperatives</a> brought about economic decline. Many Kelmendi people fled, and some were executed trying to cross the border.<sup id="cite_ref-Albanian_Nationalism_99-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Albanian_Nationalism-99">[96]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div style="clear:both;"></div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Communism">Communism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Communism_in_Albania" class="mw-redirect" title="Communism in Albania">Communism in Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Bunkers_in_Albania" title="Bunkers in Albania">Bunkers in Albania</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:HOD%C5%BDA_druh%C3%A1_m%C3%ADza_crop.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/HOD%C5%BDA_druh%C3%A1_m%C3%ADza_crop.jpg/170px-HOD%C5%BDA_druh%C3%A1_m%C3%ADza_crop.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="229" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/HOD%C5%BDA_druh%C3%A1_m%C3%ADza_crop.jpg/255px-HOD%C5%BDA_druh%C3%A1_m%C3%ADza_crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/HOD%C5%BDA_druh%C3%A1_m%C3%ADza_crop.jpg 2x" data-file-width="305" data-file-height="410"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:HOD%C5%BDA_druh%C3%A1_m%C3%ADza_crop.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
